Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: REUisME: REU In Subtropical Marine Ecosystems
Award.AbstractNarration: The Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program at the University of Texas Marine Science Institute (UTMSI) is located at the UT campus in Port Aransas, Texas. The common theme of student research projects is the interplay between natural variability and anthropogenic drivers of change in coastal ecosystems. Specific REU projects to date have focused on pressing research questions that have global implications, including impacts of land use and freshwater demand on coastal nutrient dynamics, effects of oil spills and hydrocarbons on organismal functioning, harmful algal blooms, hypoxia, spatiotemporal community interactions, and population dynamics of mobile macrofauna. South Texas experiences extremes of environmental conditions, making it an excellent natural laboratory for studying coastal dynamics in a changing environment. UTMSI faculty research spans the biological, chemical and physical processes that occur in coastal habitats, and the laboratories and research fleet are well equipped for such studies. The program is designed to raise student awareness of the conduct of science and the importance of coastal change issues, thereby preparing students to make informed decisions about their subsequent career paths. Specific activities provide exposure to the breadth of marine science, increase knowledge of ethical conduct of research, and develop crucial scientific communication skills for targeting both specialist and generalist audiences. This program will support research experiences and career training for a total of forty undergraduates over five years. Co-funding for this program will be provided by the Directorate of Biological Sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of the REU in Subtropical Marine Ecosystems (?REUisME?) site was to encourage students to pursue careers involving science and research. During the program, undergraduate students spent their summer designing and doing marine science research and learning, as a group, about scientific ethics, career options, communication skills, and graduate study. Research focused on environmental change in the coastal ocean and its ecosystems - a topic that has local and global relevance. Some examples of student projects include the impacts of land use and freshwater demand on coastal nutrient loads, effects of oil spills on organisms, and harmful algal blooms. We aimed to raise student awareness of the conduct of science and prepare students to make informed decisions about their subsequent career paths. In addition, by overcoming challenges and completing a successful project, students gain a sense of accomplishment and belief in themselves and their ability to pursue science and research as a career.

The specific goals of the program were to:

  • Develop students? skills in designing and conducting scientific research;
  • Increase students? exposure to and awareness of scientific career paths;
  • Foster an understanding of ethical conduct in scientific research; and
  • inspire students, including those from groups that are underrepresented in marine science, to pursue science careers.

Over the 4 years of the grant, 33 undergraduate students from around the country participated; 45% of our students came from institutions that did not offer significant research opportunities. At the end of each summer, we asked students about what they learned from the program, to see if we were meeting our goals. At the end of the summer, students reported an increase (4.4/5 score) in many different ways of ?feeling like a scientist.? Students also reported gains in all areas of designing and conducting research (4.2/5 score), awareness of science career paths (4.3/5 score), and understanding of scientific ethics (4.2/5 score). Our students were inspired to pursue scientific careers ? overall, students reported that participating in the program made them more likely to pursue a science career or advanced degree. Of the 33 participants, 21% pursued a post-graduate degree in a STEM field (5 Ph.D., 2 M.S.), another 24% completed their undergraduate degree and work in a STEM field, and 10% work in the medical field.
